Variable Documentation

surfit::surfit_area
 

Surface area with constant value for interpolation. Area is a closed curve (see curv). This curve is the bound of the area. Area have one parameter - the value for the cells wich centers are in area.

By loading area object to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

where are the cells indexes, which are in the area, - value of the area, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example:
  • Interpolation of areas
See also:
  • surfit_areas
  • area
  • Tcl commmands

surfit::surfit_cntr
 

3D contour for interpolation. Contour is a line in 3D which set with points . Between points countour is a straight line segment.

By loading cntr object to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

where are the cells indexes, crossed with contour, - mean value of contour for the (i,j) cell, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example:
  • Interpolation of contours
See also:
  • surfit_cntrs
  • cntr
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_completer
 

Implements so-called "completer" functional. This functional describes the surface behavior in the areas of low data density.

This functional can be written with formula:

Functional writes for each "unsolved" cell with respect of grid boundaries.

"Completer" functional can be modified using following classes:

  • surfit_wfunc and surfit_wfuncs
  • surfit_wtask and surfit_wtasks
  • surfit_wiso and surfit_wisos
  • surfit_wcntr and surfit_wcntrs
  • surfit_warea and surfit_wareas
  • surfit_flt and surfit_flts
Here is simple example of "completer" D1 and D2 variables influence:

function reconstructed by scattered data points with completer_set 0 1

function reconstructed by scattered data points with completer_set 1 5

function reconstructed by scattered data points with completer_set 1 0

Other examples:
  • map_area::tcl
  • map_cntr::tcl
  • map_flt::tcl
  • map_iso::tcl
  • map_task::tcl
  • map_warea::tcl
  • map_wcntr::tcl
  • map_wfunc::tcl
  • map_wiso::tcl
  • map_wtask::tcl
See also:
  • completer
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_defarea
 

Surface domain of definition. Using defarea (definition area) you can specify cells with undefined values.

By loading warea object to surfit memory we write the following equations:

where - are values of the cells, for which defarea returns "false".

Example :
  • Setting domain of definition

surfit::surfit_fill_with
 

Using fill_with you can set values of all unsolved cells.

By loading warea object to surfit memory we write the following equations:

where - are values of the "unsolved" cells.

See also:
  • fill_with
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_flt
 

Tectonical fault line. Fault line is a curv which breaks connection between neighbour cells, crossed with fault line. See (data for details)

To take fault line in terms of grid, fault line transforms to grid_line using modified Brezengham algorithm. After that fault line presented as a set of cell borders.

By loading flt object to surfit memory we modify completer functional:

The summands, for which two neighbour cells have the "faulted" borders will be removed from the functional.

Example :
  • Interpolation of scattered data points with faults
See also:
  • surfit_flts
  • flt
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_func
 

Function for interpolation. We describe function with values in the cells of equidistant grid


where indexes i and j denotes (i,j) cell, - value of (i,j) cell.

By loading func to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

where - funciton value in (i,j) cell. Before writing of functional, we use bilinear interpolation algortihm to recalc func to surfit_grid

About functional sequence and surfit method of function reconstruction CMOFS see data.

Example :
  • Interpolation of ordered data points
See also:
  • surfit_funcs
  • func
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_grid
 

This class describes equidistant rectangular grid (rectangular region comprised of evenly spaced rows and columns), presented with cells (intersection of a rows and columns). Each cell have center point, which is grid node. To set the grid it is necessary to specify "start" and "end" points, distance between two neighbour nodes in OX and OY directions (stepX and stepY respectively). On the picture cell border shown with dashed lines, nodes with small circles. Gridding generates a Z value at each grid node by interpolating or approximating the data values.

See also:
  • grid
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_iso
 

Isoline for interpolation. Isoline is a curv with one fixed z-value.

By loading iso object to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

where are the cells indexes, crossed with isoline, - isoline value, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example :
  • Interpolation of isolines
See also:
  • surfit_isos
  • iso
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_task
 

This class describes the set of scattered data points for surface reconstruction. Each point describes by three coordinates , where is some physical value or something else value. Use task if you want to fit data exactly.

By loading task object to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

where - cell (i,j), are the values of points belong to cell (i,j).

About functional sequence and surfit method of function reconstruction see data. For details about functions see (func).

Here is simple example. Function was reconstructed from scattered data points using following parameters for completer:

completer_set 0 1

scattered data points

function reconstructed by scattered data points

Example:
  • map_task::tcl
See also:
  • surfit_tasks
  • task
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_trend
 

Trend surface. We describe trend the same as function (func), but trend have two additional parameters D1 and D2. trend defines the result surface behavior at the areas of low information density.

By loading trend object to surfit memory we write the follow functionals to the sequence:

About functional sequence and surfit method of function reconstruction see data.

Example :
  • Interpolation of scattered data points with trend and fault
See also:
  • surfit_trends
  • trend
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_warea
 

Surface area with constant value for approximation. warea is a closed curve (see curv). This curve is the bound of warea. warea have two parameters: value for the cells with centers in warea and informational weight to control approximation. warea is analogue of area, but differs with the way of constructing functional (see data for details)

By loading warea object to surfit memory we modify completer functional:

where are the cells indexes, which are in the area, - completer functional, - area value, w - informational weight, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example :
  • Approximation of areas differs from Interpolation of areas
See also:
  • surfit_wareas
  • warea
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_wcntr
 

3D contour for approximation. Contour with weight is a line in 3D which set with points . Between points countour is a straight line segment. Additionaly wcntr have informational weight. wcntr differs from cntr with the way of constructing functional (see data for details).

By loading wcntr object to surfit memory we modify completer functional:

where are the cells indexes, crossed with contour, - completer functional, - mean value of contour for the (i,j) cell, w - informational weight, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example:
  • Approximation of contours differs from Interpolation of contours
See also:
  • surfit_wcntrs
  • wcntr
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_wfunc
 

Function for approximation. By loading wfunc object to surfit memory we modify completer functional:

where - completer functional, - value in (i,j) cell, w - informational weight. See also func.

About functional sequence and surfit method of function reconstruction (CMOFS) see data.

Examples :
  • Approximation of ordered data points
See also:
  • surfit_wfuncs
  • wfunc
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_wiso
 

Isoline for approximation. wiso is an isoline (iso) with informational weight. wiso differs from iso with the way of constructing functional (see data and surfit_iso for details)

By loading wiso object to surfit memory we modify completer functional:

where are the cells indexes, crossed with isoline, - completer functional, - isoline value, w - informational weight, - value of (i,j) cell.

Example :
  • Approximation of isolines differs from Interpolation of isolines
See also:
  • surfit_wiso
  • wiso
  • Tcl commands

surfit::surfit_wtask
 

This class describes the set of scattered data points with informational weights. These points are for surface reconstruction. Each point describes by four values , where is some physical value or something else value, - informational weight, point coordinates. You must use wtask if you don't want to fit points exactly, but if you want to approximate them.

By loading wtask object to surfit memory we modify completer functional by adding functional:

where - cell (i,j), are the values of points belong to cell (i,j).

We write completer functional with wtask functional:

About functional sequence and surfit method of function reconstruction see data. For details about functions see (func).

Example :
  • map_wtask::tcl
See also:
  • surfit_wtasks
  • wtask
  • Tcl commands
